document.discussion_title: Experts say we could be in for a messy 2016 hurricane season
document.topic_text: 10:40 Experts say we could be in for a messy 2016 hurricane season According to experts at The Weather Channel, the 2016 Atlantic hurricane season could be interesting and busy -- not good news for anyone still dealing with after-effects of Houston's latest flooding.The Weather Company, which encompasses the Weather Channel... Share on Facebook Tweet CaptionCloseAccording to experts at The Weather Channel, the 2016 Atlantic hurricane season could be interesting and busy -- not good news for anyone still dealing with after-effects of Houston's latest flooding.The Weather Company, which encompasses the Weather Channel and Weather Underground, is forecasting a total of 14 named storms, eight hurricanes and three major hurricanes, according to a report released late last week. This would make 2016 the most active season since 2012. "Major hurricanes" are those ranked Category 3 or higher. RELATED: Here's where every major Texas hurricane or tropical storm has come from since 1900RELATED: Here's where every major Texas hurricane or tropical storm has come from since 1900Hurricane season starts June 1 and wraps up Nov. 30. The United States averages up to two hurricane landfalls a season, according to NOAA statistics shared by the Weather Company. This is just a scientific forecast, of course, and anything could happen over the next seven months. Some years there are many named storms and hurricanes but few make landfall and wreck coastal areas. This report didn't include Hurricane Alex which was a January surprise earlier this year in the Azores. Thankfully, it only caused minimal damages. RELATED: January hurricane is second on recordRELATED: January hurricane is second on recordEarlier this year, University of North Carolina researchers said they were forecasting 15 to 18 tropical storms and hurricanes in 2016. Up to 11 could become hurricanes with up to five reaching major hurricane status. It is, though, important to be prepared and Houstonians got a spoonful of what Mother Nature can dish out during "hurricane season" a week ago with the Tax Day flooding. The National Hurricane Center already has a list of names for 2016 hurricanes ready to use after Hurricane Alex. Bonnie, Colin, and Danielle lead off the list.
